titleStmt.title: Letter from Mary Russell Mitford to George Colman, 18 December 1825.

sponsor.orgName: Mary Russell Mitford Society: Digital Mitford Project

editionStmt.edition: First digital edition in TEI, date: 2 August 2013. P5.

publicationStmt.authority: Digital Mitford: The Mary Russell Mitford Archive

availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

seriesStmt.title: Digital Mitford Letters: The Mary Russell Mitford Archive

notesStmt.note: Any special notes on this text? (optional)
You can have multiple notes here.

msDesc.head: Letter from Lord Montrose to George Colman 18 December, 1825.

support.p: PaperOne quarto-sized sheet sheet folded once vertically and twice horizontally, with address leaf.

Elliptical postmark in sepia ink on top fold of address leaf reading 1[8][2]5
20 DE
NIGHT. Large "3" cancellation mark over the address lines.

supportDesc.condition: Letter complete on the front of the first vertical fold of the sheet. Address leaf on back of the second fold.

sealDesc.p: The remains of a black wax seal are present in pieces at the top and bottom folds of the address leaf.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford's spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where the spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice,” “sic,” and “reg” to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p: I trouble you only to thank you for your kind attention to my request, & the implied warning. I shall not now meddle with Henry the Second--especially as I believe that I perceive the reason which induces you to think the subject a bad one.
Should any circumstance bring me to Town I shall be most happy to avail myself of your offered kindness & by a personal interview--
I have the honour to be, Sir,
div.closer:
Your very obedient ServtM. R. Mitford
ToGeorge Colman Esquire22. Brompton SqreOld Brompton
